docs.lead_paragraph: Within seconds, they could actually feel their waists begin to shrink. It would have been a great advance in the world of weight loss -- if only it had been real. But the shrinking feeling was just an illusion, created by scientists who wanted to study how the brain creates body image, people's perceptions of their own size and shape.

headline.main: Experiment Gives Illusion Of That Shrinking Feeling

docs.abstract: Dr H Henrik Ehrsson of University College (London) leads study on body image perception that pinpoints posterior parietal cortex as significant processing center; research, which is published in journal Public Library of Science, Biology, may help scientists and doctors better understanand treat anorexia nervosa (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers fooled people into feeling as if they were getting skinnier by stimulating tendons in their wrists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Christina Koenig found out she had breast cancer on a Friday afternoon. She was just 39 years old. On Monday, she thought she knew why the cancer had struck.

headline.main: Does Stress Cause Cancer? Probably Not, Research Finds

docs.abstract: Many patients who are faced with cancer diagnosis have blamed stress for their illnesses, but recent research does not support link between stress and development of cancer; Dr Polly Newcomb, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center cancer prevention program head, leads study on reported link between breast cancer and stress and finds no evidence beyond perception of individual that there is link; recent cancer research involving immune system function shows that cancer cells turn off immune system's attack; individuals with compromised immune systems show small increase in cancers that are associated with infections not common types of cancer; other studies described; photos; graphs (L)
docs.snippet: A new insight is changing the direction of research: it now appears that cancer cells make proteins that tell the immune system to leave them alone.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that cholesterol-lowering drugs like statins and fibrates may slow the course of Alzheimer's disease. The study followed the progression of 342 patients for three years. Of them, 234 had high cholesterol, and 129 of those were given medicine to lower their cholesterol.

headline.main: Drugs Found to Have Effect on Alzheimer's Disease

docs.abstract: Research published in Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry finds that cholesterol-lowering drugs like statins may slow course of Alzheimer's disease; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that cholesterol-lowering drugs like statins and fibrates may slow the course of Alzheimer's disease.      The study followed the progression of 342 patients for three years. Of them, 234 had high cholesterol, and 129 of those...

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF NEUROLOGY, NEUROSURGERY AND PSYCHIATRY

docs.lead_paragraph: Extended breast-feeding appears to lower the risk of Type 2 diabetes for the mother, The Journal of the American Medical Association reported last week. For each year that a woman breast-feeds, she reduces her risk of developing diabetes by 15 percent, the study determined.

headline.main: Breast-Feeding May Help Keep Diabetes at Bay

docs.abstract: Dr Karin B Michels, Harvard University epidemiology professor, leads study that shows women who breast-feed lower their risk of developing Type 2 diabetes; research, which is published in Journal of the American Medical Assn, finds that each year woman breast-feeds she reduces risk of diabetes by 15 percent; study looked at participants in Nurses' Health Study; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Extended breast-feeding appears to lower the risk of Type 2 diabetes for the mother, The Journal of the American Medical Association reported last week.     For each year that a woman breast-feeds, she reduces her risk of developing diabetes by 15...

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers in Scotland have found that twins have substantially lower I.Q.'s than their singleton siblings, based on a sampling of more than 10,000 Scottish children born in the 1950's. The study, published online Nov. 18 in BMJ, the British Medical Journal, concludes that at least part of the explanation lies in the reduced prenatal growth and shorter gestation typical of twins.

headline.main: Research Finds Twins to Be the Slower Siblings

docs.abstract: Scottish researchers conduct twin study that shows twins score lower on intelligence tests than their singleton siblings; acknowledge that scores were taken from children born over 50 years ago and may be different by current standards; research is published online in BMJ; suggests that difference may be related to low birth weight and shortened gestational period common for twins; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Recent research indicates that twins have substantially lower I.Q.'s than their singleton siblings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Drinking decaffeinated coffee can raise the level of L.D.L., the bad cholesterol associated with cardiovascular disease risk, new research suggests. The effect is significant, according to Dr. H. Robert Superko of the Fuqua Heart Center in Atlanta, who led the study. ''If an individual has elevated L.D.L. and wants to lower it without drugs,'' Dr. Superko said, ''a combined approach of diet, exercise, weight loss and cessation of decaffeinated coffee -- if they drink three to six cups a day -- could reduce the L.D.L. 30 percent and help avoid lifelong drug therapy.''

headline.main: With Decaf, Lose the Jitters, but Gain the Gunk?

docs.abstract: Dr H Robert Superko of Fuqua Heart Center leads study on impact of decaffeinated coffee on cholesterol levels; research, which was presented at American Heart Assn meeting, finds that individuals asked to drink 3 to 6 cups of decaffeinated coffee per day experienced significant increases in blood levels of LDL (S)
docs.snippet: Drinking decaffeinated coffee can raise the level of L.D.L., the bad cholesterol associated with cardiovascular disease risk, new research suggests.     The effect is significant, according to Dr. H. Robert Superko of the Fuqua Heart Center in...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the ''life is not fair'' department, Amy Farber and several hundred other women like her have been dealt a particularly nasty blow. They have a disease that few people, including doctors, have ever heard of -- a very rare, progressive and ultimately fatal lung disease that primarily affects young women. Its cause is unknown, and there is no effective treatment. Furthermore, the name of the disease is hardly memorable: lymphangioleiomyomatosis, (pronounced lim-FAN-zhee-oh-LYE-oh-MY-oh-muh-TOE-sis), or LAM for short.

headline.main: Hard to Pronounce, Infinitely Harder to Cure

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses lymphangioleiomyomatosis, rare lung disease commonly known as LAM; disease generally occurs in women of childbearing age; 350,000 women worldwide are believed to have LAM, but because it is so rare there is little support for finding cure; life expectancy of those who have disease ranges up to 20 years; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In the ''life is not fair'' department, Amy Farber and several hundred other women like her have been dealt a particularly nasty blow. They have a disease that few people, including doctors, have ever heard of -- a very rare, progressive and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite more than a decade's worth of research showing that taking too much of a popular pain reliever can ruin the liver, the number of severe, unintentional poisonings from the drug is on the rise, a new study reports. The drug, acetaminophen, is best known under the brand name Tylenol. But many consumers don't realize that it is also found in widely varying doses in several hundred common cold remedies and combination pain relievers. These compounds include Excedrin, Midol Teen Formula, Theraflu, Alka-Seltzer Plus Cold Medicine, and NyQuil Cold and Flu, as well as other over-the-counter drugs and many prescription narcotics, like Vicodin and Percocet.

headline.main: Poisonings From a Popular Pain Reliever Are on the Rise

docs.abstract: Research shows that unintentional poisonings from acetaminophen, Tylenol pain reliever, resulting in liver damage are on rise; because drug is used within variety of over-counter medications many individuals do not know they are exceeding recommended maximum dose of 4,000 milligrams per day; consequences of acetaminophen overdose discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The number of severe, unintentional poisonings from acetaminophen is increasing.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Green tea helps prevent cancer. THE FACTS -- It has been called an herbal panacea, able to help people who drink it regularly to lose weight, lower their cholesterol and generally safeguard their health. But when it comes to one of the most-cited benefits of green tea, its ability to fight cancer, studies have found plenty of promise and not a lot of evidence.
